When the switch is closed, the compass needle deflects monetarily, and then returns to its original orientation.
Explanation:
Just after the switch is closed, the current through the primary coil increases from zero to its maximum value.
The strength of the magnetic field produced by the primary coil increases from zero to its maximum value.
The soft iron ring redirects the magnetic field produced by the primary coil toward the secondary coil.
By Faraday’s law of electromagnetic induction, the changing magnetic flux linkage through the secondary coil induces an emf. in the secondary coil.
Since the secondary coil is part of a closed circuit, the induced e.m.f. produces an induced current through the secondary coil.
By Lenz’s law, the induced current through the secondary coil produces a magnetic field that opposes the strengthening of the magnetic field produced by the primary coil.
When this induced current through the secondary coil flows through wire PQ, it produces a magnetic field that momentarily defects the compass needle.
When the switch is opened, the compass needle deflects monetarily in the opposite direction, and then returns to its original orientation.
Explanation:
Just after the switch is opened, the current through the primary coil decreases from its maximum value to zero.
The strength of the magnetic field produced by the primary coil decreases from its maximum value to zero.
The soft iron ring redirects the magnetic field produced by the primary coil toward the secondary coil.
By Faraday’s law of electromagnetic induction, the changing magnetic flux linkage through the secondary coil induces an e.m.f. in the secondary coil in the opposite direction.
Since the secondary coil is part of a closed circuit, the induced e.m.f. produces an induced current through the secondary coil in the opposite direction.
By Lenz’s law, the induced current through the secondary coil produces a magnetic field that opposes the weakening of the magnetic field produced by the primary coil.
When this induced current through the secondary coil flows through wire PQ, it produces a magnetic field that momentarily defects the compass needle in the opposite direction.
When the switch remains closed or opened, the compass needle is remains undeflected.
Explanation:
When the switch remains closed or open, the current through the primary coil remains either constant or zero.
The strength of the magnetic field produced by the primary coil remains either constant or zero.
The soft iron ring redirects the magnetic field produced by the primary coil toward the secondary coil.
Since the magnetic flux linkage through the secondary coil is constant, no e.m.f. and no current are induced in the secondary coil.
Since wire PQ produces no magnetic field, the compass needle remains undeflected.

The coil is rotated by turning the handle.
As the coil rotates between the two magnets, the magnetic flux linkage through the coil changes at a non-uniform rate. (The coil cuts the magnetic field lines at a non-uniform rate.)
By Faraday’s law of electromagnetic induction, an e.m.f. is induced in the rotating coil. Fleming’s right hand rule tells us the direction of the induced e.m.f. in sides AD and BC.
In the closed circuit, the induced alternating current flows through the coil, the 2 slip rings, the carbon brushes and the bulb.

Function of the 2 slip rings The 2 slip rings maintain continuous electrical contact between the rotating coil and the external circuit via the carbon brushes, so that the induced current flows through the closed circuit.
The maximum induced e.m.f. of an a.c. generator can be increased by increasing the rate at which the coil cuts the magnetic field lines, e.g. by:
increasing the number of turns of the coil
increasing the magnetic field strength (e.g. stronger magnets)
increasing the speed of rotation of the coil
winding the coil on a soft iron core (to strengthen the magnetic field through the coil)
The maximum induced current can be increased by increasing the induced e.m.f. or by decreasing the resistance of the coil.
A transformer is a device that can change a large alternating voltage (with a small current) to a small alternating voltage (at large current), and vice versa.
A transformer does not work on direct current (d.c.) because a changing magnetic field is required to induce an e.m.f. in the secondary coil.
The alternating input voltage
produces an alternating current
through the primary coil. Current
produces an alternating magnetic field (which alternately increases and decreases in strength).
The laminated soft iron core
redirects
the alternating magnetic field produced by the primary coil toward the secondary coil.
By Faraday’s law of electromagnetic induction, the changing magnetic flux linkage through the secondary coil induces an alternating output voltage
in the secondary coil.
Since the secondary coil is part of a closed circuit, the alternating output voltage
produces an alternating current
through the secondary coil and the load.

The efficiency of a transformer is always less than 100% because some energy is lost as non-useful forms.
Energy is wasted due to:
energy being transferred to the internal stores of the coils when current flows through them, since the coils have some resistance.
energy being transferred to the internal store of the core when eddy current flows through core, since the core has some resistance.
leakage of magnetic field lines between the primary and secondary coils.
hysteresis loss caused by the flipping of the magnetic domains in the core due to the alternating magnetic field produced by the primary coil. Energy is transferred to the internal store of the core.
